body: Wow.
:scream:

Wow. Great! Excited to see this.

> At a high level it is an explicit non goal to enable building outside of a MinGW shell

minor nit: MinGW shell -> MSYS shell :)

> this commit alters the compiler to attach the dllexport attribute to all LLVM functions that are reachable

See also [this comment of #7196](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/7196#issuecomment-44361212). The change is, therefore, necessary to MinGW part as well.

> The flipside of this situation is that whenever you link to a dll and you import a function from it, the import should be tagged with dllimport.
> At this time, however, the compiler does not emit dllimport for any declarations other than constants (where it is required),

This is also true for MinGW/gcc side, isn't it? I've heard that [dllimport is an optimization for functions, but a requirement for data](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4489441/why-when-is-declspec-dllimport-not-needed). But then I'm curious why we haven't have such issue with gcc.

This is an _excellent_ opportunity to add [manifest support](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn195770.aspx) and take a stab at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/11207 and https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/issues/721, at least for MSVC.
(Alternatively, use [MANIFESTUAC](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb384691.aspx) and just close https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/16455)
@alexcrichton: you are a force of nature.
Between this and musl support, amazing!

@klutzy, @vadimcn 

> See also [this comment of #7196](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/7196#issuecomment-44361212). The change is, therefore, necessary to MinGW part as well.

...

> This is also true for MinGW/gcc side, isn't it? I've heard that [dllimport is an optimization for functions, but a requirement for data](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4489441/why-when-is-declspec-dllimport-not-needed). But then I'm curious why we haven't have such issue with gcc.

...

> @klutzy: gnu ld links to dll data using a bit of magic called [`auto-import`](http://blog.omega-prime.co.uk/?p=115) (edit: wrong url).

Fascinating! The article from @vadimcn was quite informative and I suspect that's why everything "just works" today. I think we may want to even investigate turning off the `auto-import` flag by default, but it may be a little late in the game to do that.

---

@vadimcn 

> @alexcrichton: `configure` seems to have a problem with msvc root path containing spaces.  What is the exact command line one is supposed to use?

Ah yeah I forgot to mention that, but `--arg="val with spaces"` is currently broken with our configure script, so I've been ensuring that `cl.exe` is in my PATH and then I invoke `./configure --host=x86_64-pc-windows-msvc,x86_64-pc-windows-gnu` in a MSYS2 shell.

@cmr 

> This is an excellent opportunity to add manifest support and take a stab at #11207 and rust-lang/rfcs#721, at least for MSVC.

...

> (Alternatively, use MANIFESTUAC and just close #16455)

I think for now I might hold off on trying to tackle these problems. I suspect that if `link.exe` has official support for manifest (and if GNU ld does not) that it should be easy enough for builds to use `-C link-args`, and otherwise adding some sort of interface for this would require adding API surface area to the compiler itself. Definitely possible to solve in the near future, but may best wait for a follow-up PR.
Crikey - when I named that commit "Very hacky MSVC hacks." it was to try and make sure it didn't make it into a real rust branch without being heavily rebased! Nice work! :D
\o/ I'm going to try this out later this week. Nice work! :smile:

@luser @indygreg From the build system perspective, is this enough for Rust-in-Gecko (i.e. ignoring debug symbols and the rest for now)? As mentioned in the PR it doesn't attempt to allow for builds outside of an msys shell.

@Manishearth Rust still requires an msys shell to be built, however you do not need an msys shell to merely use Rust. This PR should be enough for Rust-in-Gecko, so long as you don't need unwinding or debug symbols.
Oh, I see. That should be fine then :D

@Manishearth This all sounds pretty sensible, although as we discussed we are going to need debug symbols in order to ship any Rust code in Firefox. I thought someone (jrmuizel?) told me that LLVM had support for outputting CodeView debug info in object files?

I'm not sure whether unwinding is a hard requirement for us, aside from "generate unwind info in the debug info". We do use SEH in a few places in Gecko, but these are primarily for calling out to third-party code that can fault on us (and which we can reasonably ignore faults for):
https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/search?q=MOZ_SEH_TRY&case=true

> jemalloc is currently unconditionally disabled for MSVC targets as jemalloc isn't a hard requirement and I don't know how to build it with MSVC.

So this raises an interesting question that I hadn't realized--Gecko builds its own jemalloc on all platforms, can we make Rust code use our jemalloc instead of trying to provide another copy?

> although as we discussed we are going to need debug symbols in order to ship any Rust code in Firefox

Yeah; I was focusing on the build issues for now.

> I thought someone (jrmuizel?) told me that LLVM had support for outputting CodeView debug info in object files?

http://clang.llvm.org/docs/MSVCCompatibility.html ? I guess we'll need to patch up our debuginfo support to include this? cc @michaelwoerister 

> So this raises an interesting question that I hadn't realized--Gecko builds its own jemalloc on all platforms, can we make Rust code use our jemalloc instead of trying to provide another copy?

I believe Rust can be built to use a custom allocator. I'm not sure though.

@Manishearth 

> As mentioned in the PR it doesn't attempt to allow for builds outside of an msys shell.

To confirm what @retep998 said, this does not require that the compiler itself be run from a msys shell, just building the compiler itself. Rust today does not need to be run from an msys shell, and this PR does not change that.

---

@luser 

> This all sounds pretty sensible, although as we discussed we are going to need debug symbols in order to ship any Rust code in Firefox.

Currently this PR is just the bare-bones to get the compiler to bootstrap so we can start setting up automation and testing for all of this, but so long as LLVM has support for this then it's probably not too hard for us to support it!

> I'm not sure whether unwinding is a hard requirement for us, aside from "generate unwind info in the debug info".

It looks like upstream LLVM has lots more support for SEH unwinding than the current revision we're using, and I plan on updating our version of LLVM soon so we can bind this support as well, so this should all be coming soon!

> So this raises an interesting question that I hadn't realized--Gecko builds its own jemalloc on all platforms, can we make Rust code use our jemalloc instead of trying to provide another copy?

Currently there's not a great story for doing this, unfortunately. When building the standard library itself you can disable our bundled version of jemalloc, and in this scenario Rust just allocates memory via malloc/free/realloc/etc. There is currently no means to take a binary copy of the standard library and request that generated binaries/libraries do not use the bundled jemalloc. There have been many discussions on this in the past though, and it's something we'd very much like to do!

Right now I suspect that Rust in Gecko is likely using a separate instance of the jemalloc allocator, which I suspect is far from ideal!

@brson I have now added on a patch that fixes up `make dist` for MSVC and I believe that this is now all good and ready to go. I built a tarball and installed it locally and was able to compile and link against programs in the MSVC shell.

@vadimcn ok a lot of the recent changes to the `configure` script should make MSVC detection much more robust. Neither `--msvc-root` nor `PATH` munging is required and a bad python is also detected which will break LLVM's CMake build.

I attempted to build this branch, but when it attempted to link something, it ended up calling the wrong link. :rage: 
https://gist.github.com/2600caa5da0463aee7eb
@retep998 yeah, just put the right link higher in your PATH.

@cmr But @alexcrichton just made it so that it would find msvc using the registry and that I wouldn't have to have it in my `PATH` to begin with. If I still have to manually add it to my `PATH`, then that defeats the purpose of the registry stuff.
Oh, sorry, missed that patch. Not sure what's happening, then...

Excited but cautious. In the latest version of VS2015 they added support for Android NDK compilation for windows. If the msvc backend takes off, what will be the effort required to make everything tie up together and allow Android Rust development on Windows?

@retep998 oh right, of course! I forgot about that part. I'll see if I can't tweak the build system to make sure that shows up in PATH first.

@pakoito interesting! I suspect we may need some extra build system or porting integration to get compilation to Android working from Windows, but it shouldn't be too hard!

This all looks fine to me, except that I'm concerned with [this change](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/25350#commitcomment-11250483) that puts custom tools into the target directory. It doesn't seem very future-proof per my comment.

@brson OK I have cleaned up the commits and rebased everything, I'm going to do a full build locally again to make sure it all works, and I will also run this through dev on buildbot to make sure it bootstraps there as well. Once those pass I will r=you (pending other comments)!
@bors: r=brson cb3071b
:hourglass: Testing commit cb3071b with merge 43cf733...

:sunny: Test successful - [auto-linux-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-nopt-t/builds/5027), [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/5034), [auto-linux-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-nopt-t/builds/4989), [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/5013), [auto-linux-64-x-android-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-x-android-t/builds/4984), [auto-mac-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-32-opt/builds/5059), [auto-mac-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-nopt-t/builds/5053), [auto-mac-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-opt/builds/5024), [auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t/builds/2), [auto-win-gnu-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-opt/builds/2), [auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t/builds/2), [auto-win-gnu-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-opt/builds/2)
\o/ Congrats @alexcrichton! Now enjoy some well-deserved time off :)
:heart:

@alexcrichton,

I have two suggestions:
1. Declare VS2015 (currently RC, will be RTMd before Windows 10 launch: 29th July?) as minimum requirement to build Rust source code.
2. Remove all the guarded inclusions and C99 fallback implementations for VS < v2015 and avoid all (well [most of](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2015/04/29/c-11-14-17-features-in-vs-2015-rc.aspx)) the non-std code for MSVC. ;)

Since there is VS2015's full featured 'community' and 'express-for-desktop' versions available for free of cost, the Windows users will have enough choices: MinGW, VS2015 pro/ultimate/express-for-desktop/community to build the Rust solution.

Besides, you guys have made the win32 installer available for mainstream consumer. Building from scratch is only for enthusiasts and contributors, so I don't see it as a real deal-breaker.

Note that two main Windows supporting CI systems: AppVeyor and Jenkins already support VS2015 RC. :)

@jasonwilliams200OK thanks for the suggestions! So far we have so little C code we haven't run too much into VS compatibility just yet, but seems like sound advice regardless! We do actually currently run in AppVeyor today as well (I set up CI for a bunch of our crates over the weekend), so we're looking pretty good on that front!

In terms of the CRT stuff has [some discussion](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/26258), but we may try to actually be totally independent of the CRT in the standard library, which would be quite nice!

> Declare VS2015 (currently RC, will be RTMd before Windows 10 launch: 29th July?) as minimum requirement to build Rust source code.

Yeah, I have the same _feeling_, mostly because of the CRT rewrite, but I don't know what would be the practical consequences of not supporting VS2013 (and <VS2013 can't be used anyway because it can't build LLVM).

> we may try to actually be totally independent of the CRT in the standard library, which would be quite nice!

@alexcrichton, sounds like a great plan. :+1: 
There are some more cool bits around CRT and such:
- Clang on Windows (sporting CRT integration) http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2015/05/01/bringing-clang-to-windows.aspx  (related: https://github.com/microsoft/clang)
- This fork of LLVM: https://github.com/microsoft/llvm has some Windows related fixes and it keeps in sync with upstream llvm (and mostly used for https://github.com/dotnet/llilc).
- A Universal CRT is introduced recently for Windows XP to Windows 10: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2015/03/03/introducing-the-universal-crt.aspx.

@petrochenkov, while installing [VS 2015 requires at least Windows 7](https://www.visualstudio.com/visual-studio-2015-system-requirements-vs#VSC_RC), it can [build for targets as far back as Windows XP](https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/products/visual-studio-2015-compatibility-vs.aspx) (info for the RC, but that shouldn't change for RTM).
If VS2015 is only required to build the toolchain, and not a requirement for linking Rust code with the compiler then it's probably fine.
